awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Confinement and Surface Effects on Heterogeneous Reactions with Diffusion in Nano-Porous Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Keith Gubbins of North Carolina State University and Liping Huang of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute are receiving an award from the Theory, Models and Computational Methods program of the Chemistry Division. The project  goal is the development and application of novel simulation methods for the discovery of confinement and surface effects on heterogeneous reactions with diffusion in nano-porous materials. The focus of  the study is to provide a molecular level understanding of the mechanisms of adsorption, diffusion and reaction as well as the interplay among them. To that end, a suite of methods spanning the electronic, atomistic and continuum scales are developed to treat simultaneously reaction, diffusion and adsorption. These methods are projected to combine density functional theory, time dependent density functional theory, advanced optimization techniques, non-equilibrium and rare event molecular dynamics, and continuum modeling, and are able to accommodate temperature and pressure gradients, thus simulating experimental conditions. Hence, the simulation strategy reuses existing codes within a novel multiscale approach.

The research is at the interface of chemistry and materials engineering research and design.  Improved multiscale methods for studying chemical reactions under realistic conditions provide a route to deeper understanding of the roles of diffusion and adsorption in heterogeneous reactions. The ability to predict the combined effect of these phenomena impacts a broad range of technologies, and is essential to the design of new reactive schemes for reducing energy demand and environmental impact. Graduate and undergraduate students working on this project learn modern multiscale modeling methods, and gain experience of international cooperative research through active collaborations with researchers in Japan, Poland, China and Hong Kong. Graduate students from under-represented groups are recruited through a bridging program and an existing AGEP program with HBCUs in the area, and through NCSU's Women in Science & Engineering program. At RPI, Huang is actively participating in New Visions: Math, Engineering, Technology and Science, a high school outreach program that provides advanced placement courses for students at rural schools in upstate New York.

The award is co-funded by a pilot program of the Office of Cyberinfrastructure.

por.por_cntn:
This project concerned the development of theoretical and computational methods to study chemical reactions on solid surfaces and within porous supports, and the use of these to study several specific reactions, including the dissociation of water into hydrogen and oxygen on titanium dioxide surfaces, the reaction of amino acids on carbon materials, and the polymerization of sulfur inside carbon nanotubes. Such heterogeneous reactions are widely used in the chemical, oil and gas, food and pharmaceutical industriest to make a wide variety of chemical products. The outcomes of this work included the following:

1. Titanium dioxide surfaces can have a variety of forms, and these differ markedly in their reactivity towards water.  We discovered that the most promising surface for the dissociation of water was the rutile (001) surface of titanium dioxide.

2. Knowledge of the adsorption behavior of various amino acids on different solid surfaces is important in the design of drug delivery systems.  We studied five common amino acids on different graphite oxide surfaces. We showed that tryptophan dissociated on such surfaces, but that other amino acids, in particular alanine, histidine and proline adsorb on graphite oxide surfaces.  Moreover, we found that such adsorption was enhanced if carboxyl groups were bonded to the graphite oxide surface.

3. Sulfur is normally an insulator, but it has been shown recently in experiments that when the sulfur is adsorbed into a carbon nanotube of suitable diameter, it forms a conducting metallic phase.  This phase consists of sulfur atoms bonded together into a linear chain.  We have shown that this conducting property is due to very high pressures on the sulfur atoms, and that these high pressures result from strong intermolecular forces between the sulfur atoms and the walls. These findings suggest that other novel materials can occur by confining various elements and compounds within carbon nanotubes, the diameter of the nanotube being tailored to produce very high pressures, resulting in new conducting, semi-conducting and super-conducting phases of matter.  This would open a new field of materials chemistry, and such materials are likely to find numerous applications in the future.

4.  We developed a new method to calculate the pressure in fluids and materials having a cylindrical geometry, for example cylindrical micelles (surfactant molecules such as detergents, can arrange themselves in a cylindrical form, surrounded by water) and fluids confined within narrow pores of cylindrical shape. This method will provide a way to calculate pressures within many new synthetic porous materials, including silicas, oxides and carbons.  These materials are of interest for the preparation of high pressure materials and for carrying out high pressure reactions in industry.

5. Three doctoral students and one undergraduate student participated in this research. All three of the graduate students completed their Ph.D., and two of these, Jeremy Palmer and Liangliang Huang, now occupy tenure-track faculty positions at the University of Houston and the University of Oklahoma, respectively.  The undergraduate student, Andrew Santos, completed his B.S. degree with honors and is now pursuing the Ph.D. degree at Princeton University.  All of these students received training in quantum mechanics, statistical mechanics, molecular simulation and the application of these methods to the study of chemical reactions in novel environments. The graduate students also participated in international research cooperation with research groups in Japan, Singapore and Germany, and so gained experience in international cooperation.

6.  This research project resulted in 8 scientific papers published in international scientific journals.  In addition, the results of the work were disseminated through our website and through numerous lectures and presentations at national and international conferences by the Principal Investigator and by the students involved.
